componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the net NetApp Third Quarter Fiscal Year 2015 Financial Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now turn the call over to Kris Newton, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hello, and thank you for joining us in our Q3 fiscal year 2015 earnings call. With me today are CEO, Tom Georgens; and CFO, Nick Noviello. This call is being webcast live and will be available for replay on our website at netapp.com, along with the earnin
componenttext:
Hello, and thank you for joining us in our Q3 fiscal year 2015 earnings call. With me today are CEO, Tom Georgens; and CFO, Nick Noviello. This call is being webcast live and will be available for replay on our website at netapp.com, along with the earnings release, our financial tables, a historical supplemental table and a non-GAAP to GAAP reconciliation.
As a reminder, during today's call, we will make forward-looking statements and projections with respect to our financial outlook and future prospects, such as over guidance for the fourth quarter and full year fiscal 2015, all of which involve risks and uncertainties. Such statements reflect our best judgment based on factors currently known to us and are being made as of today. We disclaim any obligation to update our forward-looking statements and projections. Actual results may differ materially from our statements and projections for a variety of reasons. We describe some of these reasons in our accompanying press release, which we furnished to the SEC on the Form 8-K.
Please refer to the documents we file from time to time with the SEC, specifically of our Form 10-K for fiscal year 2014, subsequent Form 10-Q quarterly report and our current reports on Form 8-K, all of which can be found on our website.
During the call, we will discuss non-GAAP financial measures. These non-GAAP measures are not prepared in accordance of generally accepted accounting principles. A reconciliation of our GAAP and non-GAAP results is provided in today's press release and on our website.
I'll now turn the call over to Tom for his commentary on the quarter.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kris, and good afternoon, everyone. We are clearly disappointed with our top line performance in Q3 and are committed to taking the steps necessary to get back on track.Despite the soft revenue, we delivered another quarter of solid operation
componenttext:
Thank you, Kris, and good afternoon, everyone. We are clearly disappointed with our top line performance in Q3 and are committed to taking the steps necessary to get back on track.
Despite the soft revenue, we delivered another quarter of solid operational performance with improved gross margin from Q3 year ago and non-GAAP operating margin and at the high end of our prior guidance. We've further reduced diluted share count and delivered EPS within our previous guidance range. We remain confident in the fundamentals of our business and continued to make progress against our hybrid cloud strategy.
Top line revenue finished below the low end of our guidance, impacted by greater-than-anticipated FX movement in the quarter, which Nick quantify shortly, as well as our own sales execution issues. EMEA and APAC were impacted by FX, U.S. Public Sector's driven by strong performance in federal had the highest growth, but Americas commercial fell short of expectation.
The Americas team bullied the increase in enterprise large deal activity in the first half of the fiscal year was optimistic about their forecast. Deals over $1 mils increased yet again in Q3, but we also saw a significant number of large deals slip out of the quarter. We have new leadership in global and Americas sales, and I'm confident in the team and fully expect the execution to improve.
Looking ahead, we see FX headwinds affecting growth for not only NetApp, but our customers as well. As companies lower their revenue expectations for The coming calendar year, there is an increase deferral of IT projects. We clearly so that in January. The anticipated budget was no longer available as companies delivered updated spending targets for the new calendar year and deals that were pushed out may not return in the near term. We are seeing large tech refresh opportunities being replaced with 1-year support renewals and in the case customers remain committed to NetApp, but do not have budget to operate at this time.
Despite the revenue shortfall, we continue to make progress in key areas. As I mentioned earlier, Q3 marked our third consecutive quarter of growth in large deals, a point of validation of our enterprise strategy. In November, we further delivered against our data fabric vision with the availability of NetApp Private Storage for IBM SoftLayer, the SteelStore appliance and Cloud ONTAP or Amazon Web Services.
We also introduced the newest version of Data ONTAP, the industry's #1 storage operating system, Data ONTAP 8.3. To date, ONTAP 8.3 has had the fastest ramp of any of our Clustered ONTAP release introductions. Shipments of clustered nodes grew 160% from Q3 a year ago. The attach rate of Clustered ONTAP continues to increase and now stands at roughly 40% of fast controllership in the quarter.
Total system units shipped increased 9% from Q3 last year. We saw notable strength in E-Series branded and configurations of all-flash. The entire portfolio has been refreshed over the past year with the recent launch of the E560 and the EF560. We continue to see sustained momentum with our broad flash portfolio as flash capacity shipped grew 69% year-over-year.
With FlashRay innovation injected into all-flash and the new EF560, we anticipate that our all-flash array systems will soon hold 2 of the top spots in the industry proponents benchmark.
ONTAP insight also continue to perform well with the a number of deals increasing from Q3 a year ago. Overall, we are confident with our portfolio and pleased with the growth of our margin products.
As we have discussed in the past, both the market and enterprise IT are undergoing a major transition. Likewise, NetApp has been undergoing a decision to position ourselves for the future as we talked about at our Analyst Day last June. The NetApp Data Fabric mission, our seamless hybrid cloud strategy, is up leveraging the nature of the conversations we're having with customers. We have delivered an unprecedented portfolio expansion, including new offerings in flash, object and cloud integration. We further augmented that integration with the SteelStore product line acquisition. We have also had highlighted the internal productivity, efficiency and supply line initiatives that have resulted in gross margin and operating margin improvements, despite a very challenging growth environment. We have increased emphasis on our enterprise and cloud service provider customers, while maintaining the memento we have in mid-sized business.
We are seeing progress on our go-to-market transformation, but it's still a work in process and in need of ongoing improvement and investment. The increase the breadth of the portfolio and our compelling data fabric vision are yielding positive results, it is clear that to fully realize the brand value of these new capabilities, we must expand our go-to-market capacity with greater product coverage, product specialists and partner enablement. Clustered Data ONTAP currently needs the technical requirements of our largest and most demanding customers. We believe NetApp's engagement helping them execute the transition to Clustered ONTAP over the next year will unlock the tech refreshes.
In prior years, go-to-market capacity expansion in times of high confidence in the portfolio proved to be a growth driver, even in difficult environments. We believe we are in a similar situation today. We also understand to delivering shareholder value in a low growth environment and the resulting pressure on operating expenses. We will continue to employ the discipline of shifting resources away from lower-yield activities, as well as driving productivity and efficiency through the organization to offset as much as possible the impact of high priority investments to expand capacity.
Overall, the growth of the emerging products, the uptick of Clustered ONTAP and the residence of our mission customers as well as our operational focus have been on a positive trajectory. All of this only compounds our disappointment with our performance last quarter. External factors, such as FX, was a clear headwinds, but our focus is on our own issues on what it takes to get back on track. We do not see any change to our strategic priorities and we'll aggressively seek to maximize return on our product portfolio within the confines of our business model.
I will now turn the call over to Nick to provide details on Q3 and our guidance for Q4 before returning with summary comments.
Nick?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. NetApp delivered strong non-GAAP gross margin and operating margin in fiscal Q3, underscoring the resiliency of our business model. We delivered non-GAAP EPS within our previous guidance
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. NetApp delivered strong non-GAAP gross margin and operating margin in fiscal Q3, underscoring the resiliency of our business model. We delivered non-GAAP EPS within our previous guidance range. However, as Tom indicated, the impact of unfavorable foreign exchange, combined with our own sales execution challenges, presented headwinds in Q3 and resulted in revenue below our expectations.
Net revenues of $1.55 billion were up about 1% sequentially, but down 4% year-over-year. FX headwinds reduced year-over-year revenue comparison by about 1.5 points , only 1 point of which we had anticipated when we gave revenue guidance from Q3 90 days ago.
Product revenue of $930[ph] million was down 8% year-over-year. The combination of soft atonement maintenance and service revenues totaling $622 million was up 5% year-over-year. Branded revenue was 92% of net revenues for Q3 and at $1.43 billion was flat sequentially, but down 2% year-over-year due to a combination of unfavorable foreign exchange and execution challenges in our Americas Commercial sales geography. Adjusted for FX, branded revenue would have been about flat year-over-year.
OEM revenue, which is transacted in U.S. dollar was $124 million in Q3, up 4% sequentially, but down 21% on a year-over-year basis as expected. Indirect revenue through the channels and OEMs accounted for 81% of Q3 net revenues. Arrow and Avnet contributed 22% and 16% of net revenues, respectively.
Non-GAAP gross margin of 64.6% was up just over 1 point from Q3 last year and just above our prior guidance range, despite FX headwinds. Non-GAAP product gross margin of 57% was relatively flat year-over-year, driven by unfavorable mix and FX, partially offset by continued supply chain execution. Sequentially, non-GAAP product gross margin was down just over 1 point due to mix.
Service gross margins of 64.5% was 3.7 points above Q3 of last year and 1.8 points above Q2 due to higher services revenues and lower spending.
Non-GAAP operating margin for the third quarter was 18.5%, at the high end of our previous guidance range. Non-GAAP operating expenses were 46% of revenue.
Consistent with our expectations on non-GAAP effective tax rate for the third quarter was 16.5%.
Q3 weighted average diluted share count of 317 million shares was below our prior guidance, down 6 million shares sequentially and down 29 million shares or 8% from Q3 last year due to continued stock repurchase activity. Non-GAAP EPS of $0.75 was inline with our prior guidance range and reflects the net impact of year-over-year FX headwinds of $0.02.
Our balance sheet remains healthy. We ended the quarter with approximately $5.3 billion in cash and investments, 13% of which is onshore. The sequential decrease in onshore cash was predominantly due to shares repurchased and dividends paid in the quarter. Inventory turns were at 19 and day sales outstanding was 39. Deferred revenue was $3.1 billion, up 2% sequentially and up 5% year-over-year.
Q3 cash from operations was $275 million and free cash flow was 68%[ph] of revenue, impacted by an increase in days sales outstanding due to unfavorable linearity.
In Q3, we returned $251 million to shareholders, which included $200 million in share repurchases and $51 million in cash dividends. Consistent with the guidance we provided last May, we remain on track to complete the remaining $206 million of our current share repurchase program by the end of May 2015, a year ahead of our original schedule.
Over the last few years, we have developed our capital structure and delivered on our commitment to return capital to shareholders while continuing to invest in the business. Through dividends and share repurchases, we have returned a total of $3.2 billion to shareholders since May 2013. We are well-positioned to move ahead with the next phase of our capital allocation strategy.
I am pleased to announce that we have increased the size of our share repurchase authorization by $2.5 billion. We intend to complete this additional $2.5 billion share repurchase program by the end of May 2018, with the first $1 billion of repurchases expected to be completed by the end of May 2016.
Today, we also announced our net cash dividend of $0.165 per share of the company stock to be paid on April 23, 2015. We remain committed to increasing our dividend over time.
Enhancements to our capital allocation strategy reflect our confidence and the long-term strength of NetApp's business, as well as our ongoing commitment increasing shareholder value. We have structured the capital allocation plan to ensure flexibility to support innovation and growth initiatives, the timing and amount of repurchase transactions under the program as well as future dividends and dividend increases will depend on market conditions, business and financial considerations and regulatory requirements.
Now to guidance. We remain confident in our strategy and competitive position. However, based on our own sales execution issues and the continued challenging IT spending environment, we are building a degree of caution into our top line expectations. We also expect FX headwinds to continue and impact year-over-year comparisons.
As a result, our target revenue range for Q4 is $1.55 billion to $1.65 billion, which, at the midpoint, implies 3% sequential growth but a 3% decline in revenue versus Q4 last year. Based on current rate, we have embedded an FX headwinds of $50 million into our Q4 revenue guidance.
We expect our strong value proposition to continue to resonate with customers, and we will have an ongoing focus on supply-chain efficiencies. with that said, we expect non-GAAP gross margins of approximately 63% to 63.5% in Q4, including about 1 point of FX headwinds. We expect non-GAAP operating margins of approximately 17% to 17.5%, reflecting about 1 point of FX headwind as well as investments in our go-to-market capacity.
Based on our repurchases in Q3, we expect Q4 diluted share count of approximately 319 million shares, down 5% versus last year. We expect non-GAAP earnings per share for Q4 to range from approximately $0.70 to $0.75 per share, which reflects about $0.05 of dilution from unfavorable foreign exchange versus last year.
Our full year fiscal 2015 revenue will be lower than anticipated due to currency headwinds and incremental caution entering Q4, which I referenced earlier. EPS is expected to be flat from FY '14 due to affects headwinds, revenue softness and investments in the business, offset by gross margin improvement ensure purchases.
In closing, our product portfolio is as strong as it's ever been and our discussions with customers continue, to involve the mark strategic levels. Our capital allocation strategy continues to reflect confidence in our ability to generate significant free cash flow, which will enable us to invest both organically and organically inorganically in the business as well as return significant capital to our shareholders through share repurchases and dividends. The investments we're making today position us to fully take advantage of the opportunity ahead, and we expect to emerge from the this transition with greater levels of growth and profitability. Through this evolution, we remain committed to our business model and to delivering shareholder value.
Now I would like to turn back to Tom first summary comments. Tom.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Nick. We remain confident in our business, but continue to operate in a challenging environment. We faced ongoing macroeconomic uncertainties on FX headwinds. Our industry is in transition as enterprises manage their existing infrastructure to mee
componenttext:
Thanks, Nick. We remain confident in our business, but continue to operate in a challenging environment. We faced ongoing macroeconomic uncertainties on FX headwinds. Our industry is in transition as enterprises manage their existing infrastructure to meet the current and growing demands of the business while adopting new technologies and delivery options. Our solutions and technology vision are also well suited to help customers meet both of these requirements.
This will play key role in creating value for enterprise customers, and we want to accelerate their ability to realize that value. Enterprise will deploy a hybrid model with both cloud-based and on-premise resources on their IT environments. Our NetApp Data Fabric vision provides customers with the only consistent way to manage, secure and protect their data regardless of where they choose to store it. The NetApp Data Fabric data elements of a hybrid cloud into a single, integrated architecture, giving customers control and choice with the flexibility, elasticity and ubiquity of cloud resources.
Data ONTAP is the foundation of the NetApp Data Fabric. Clustered Data ONTAP delivers true software defined functionality with a set of enterprise-wide data management capabilities, independent of the underlying hardware. Clustered ONTAP enables customers to grow incrementally and nondisruptively with the flexibility of a wide range of deployment options, from converged and integrated systems, to third party arrays as well as software only and cloud options.
We are confident in our ability to help customers that advantage in the evolving IP landscape. Our data fabric vision and portfolio data management solutions offer differentiated approach that improves the economics and flexibility of customers existing infrastructure, while giving on path the hybrid cloud future. Our best-of-breed solutions are compelling for existing requirements and are integrated into our broader vision for the hybrid cloud that only NetApp can deliver.
The investments we are making in our go-to-market capacity and an accelerating the migration to Clustered ONTAP, demonstrate the strength of our conviction in our technology and our strategy. During this transition, we remain committed to our business model and delivering shareholder value. Our expanded repurchase authorization exemplifies this commitment. We expect to come through the transition in a stronger position with a high level of growth and profitability.
Before moving to Q&A, I would like to thank the NetApp team for their commitment. Despite the challenging environment, we are making the right to assist and remain focused on innovation and execution, which enable us to deliver value to our customers and yields solid operational returns.
We will now open up the call for Q&A. [Operator Instructions]. Thank you.
Operator?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Sherri, in terms of Q3 -- in terms of product revenue for Q3, it was all there. So it's about 2 points on product revenue from the FX side of the fence. You have to remember that the SEM line and the services line are substantially coming in off the
componenttext: Yes, Sherri, in terms of Q3 -- in terms of product revenue for Q3, it was all there. So it's about 2 points on product revenue from the FX side of the fence. You have to remember that the SEM line and the services line are substantially coming in off the balance sheet. So the FX is really pointed at the product side of the fence.

componenttext: A little bit about the execution issues, I guess, to start, what gives you confidence that it is execution issues rather than competitive or secular? And I guess, what can you go into the issues a little bit more in particular and how you do intend to fix that going forward?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, from the question about whether it be secular or competitive, effectively, what we're talking about here, what we saw pushed out were actually deals in the committed pipeline. So it wasn't a question of we didn't have pipeline and we didn't
componenttext: Well, I think, from the question about whether it be secular or competitive, effectively, what we're talking about here, what we saw pushed out were actually deals in the committed pipeline. So it wasn't a question of we didn't have pipeline and we didn't have deals that we're pursuing. This are deals that the salesforce had committed that reflected in our forecast, reflected in our guidance and reflected in our planning as the quarter proceeded. And so not surprisingly, Monday the quarter ended, I was with a head for Americas sales and went to what happened to these deals? They went to a relatively long list of deals, 2 pages worth, deals that were committed that we expect to account but didn't come in. And all of them have a story of which competitive and lost deals was a trivially small amount of that. So from a competitive perspective, I'd say first and foremost, competitive wasn't it a key component, some of it clearly was closeable deals that we didn't get done. And after [indiscernible], some of them were changes in customer behavior, with a change of the calendar year and companies looking at their own financial forecast, their own FX impact, we certainly saw the deals that were there. The other thing is in order for deals to be in the committed pipeline, there are deals for which substantially, we have 1 difficult technical a lot of these transactions is effectively over. So it's really about the customers changing budgets, requiring more scrutiny in their approval process or fundamentally thinking about their new budget in the new calendar year. I think onward clearly, when that the watch this a little both posted, we certainly see elongated sales cycle earlier in the quarter, but the forecast has remained unchanged, the team was still relatively bullish about pulling it out. So I think that's we need to look at some of the data points along the way. Certainly, we need to inspect a lot closer and you can argue that the other side of this and the message the team is there's uncertainty about closing deals, you need more deals. So what are we going to do to enhance the pipeline. So clearly, we'll be watching this closely. As we look at our productivity, whether it be pipeline generation, per rep, or -- and even despite the quarter, in terms of actually bookings per rep, the numbers are actually quite high, relatively high in our history. So sales force productivity is still pretty high, yet we didn't get these deals closed. But the feeling is it isn't like the sales force can't sell or productivity is down, that will be more of an indicator of a product problem or there's no opportunity out there. And so feeling as a loss productivity aside, that people are generating abundant peak levels historically, that if we can put more feet on the street and get more people buying out there selling the product, we could drive some more business. So that, of course, has a lead time associated with it and hiring and bringing up to speed. By the end of the day, we would have these deals in the committed pipeline, we wouldn't have the pipeline productivity we had unless we felt strongly about the portfolio and the portfolio was resonating. So I think where we are now, I don't think product is our issue, I think capacity is our issue and that's the bet we're making. And that what you will see from us going to forward.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Keith Bachman of Bank of Montreal.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Keith Bachman of Bank of Montreal.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Tom, I wanted to follow on Maynard's question. Clearly, every enterprise company is suffering from FX. And so let's remove that from the conversation, but we haven't heard many or very, very few companies talk about elongated sales cycles in the current m
componenttext: Tom, I wanted to follow on Maynard's question. Clearly, every enterprise company is suffering from FX. And so let's remove that from the conversation, but we haven't heard many or very, very few companies talk about elongated sales cycles in the current macro with the recent string of companies that have reported, including Cisco tonight. As I just wanted to try to understand, what's your thoughts on why NetApp in particular seems to be seeing some issues on deferrals or pipeline not coming through? Is it something related to the storage side in particular? But just want to get some more thoughts about what you think NetApp in particular is seeing some of those elongated sales cycles?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, a few things. I think some of those, I'll say, I think, we quite know, I think we need more that all we need is our own point of view here. So some receive the FX as purely mathematical exercise, we get that. Likewise, we see FX not only in
componenttext: Well, I think, a few things. I think some of those, I'll say, I think, we quite know, I think we need more that all we need is our own point of view here. So some receive the FX as purely mathematical exercise, we get that. Likewise, we see FX not only in our industry, but we also see FX impact on our customers and that lead through the decisions that they make. So didn't really know the answer to your question, and so was actually more companies that are reporting generate quarters. So our assumption is FX ins purely mathematical and everything else is our responsibility to get into a fix. And like I said, if you look at these individual accounts, there's no doubt that we have closable deals that we didn't get done in time and that's pure execution and those will fall into Q4. But we've also seen elongated approval cycles, and we've also seen people reevaluating what their plans are for the year now that the calendar year changed. People thought they had budget when we put this in the pipeline that don't now. and I think the return of those transaction is yet unknown. So I think from our perspective, we just clearly need to do better on that. I'm certainly not ready to say there's a bullet unless I see some more data points. But from our point of view is that we're going to focus on our deals and our pipeline and we're going to do a better job of executing this quarter.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Tom, is everything on track the first 2 months and the wheels kind of came off the last month of the quarter?
componenttext: Tom, is everything on track the first 2 months and the wheels kind of came off the last month of the quarter?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly the forecast hadn't deteriorated materially over provide -- at the beginning. So we were obviously, this is a quarter were you've got kind of the end-of-the-quarter push and you've got the end-of-the-calendar year push, which is a little b
componenttext: Well, certainly the forecast hadn't deteriorated materially over provide -- at the beginning. So we were obviously, this is a quarter were you've got kind of the end-of-the-quarter push and you've got the end-of-the-calendar year push, which is a little bit different than other quarters. But from our point of view is, certainly, we saw bullishness going into the end of the year and still we have expectation of a relatively strong normal quarter and in January and a fair amount of that business didn't through the way we would have thought. So I think we do see the budget flush, maybe we can debate whether it's robustness or [indiscernible], but certainly close enough. We certainly had a lot of January business that was the normal part of our final month of the quarter that we see being back-end loaded, that didn't come in. And like I said, every deal has a story. But when you go through 40 deals and only 1 or 2 are competitive and the rest of them are deal-specific, I don't think the competition is really the issue. And on top of the, the field from the field was in the optimistic quarter. We still did a record number or increased number of million-dollar deals. So it wasn't like they were searching for business, they had businesses that they have, that there's wind up and I thought they wouldn't close and they did.

componenttext: Tom, with respect to the deferral spending you're talking about, I guess, after period of time or it's already been a prolonged period of deferral. So I guess, at some point, your customers in the install base need to spend too much despite all the efficiencies out there, we send that helping your visibility out there. I'm just kind of curious how growth stories in the industry? Finally, so I'm curious as to how you would think about that dynamic going through last year? And now having this either the ship and then clarification is this deferral of spending that you talked about, unit relief assuming any in the near term, just to be clear, just to be conservative, is that correct?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, certainly, you don't. And with the supplies that we have, with committed deals didn't close and that assume they're all going to come back that simply, I think, clearly, we need to derate some of the feedback that we get and I think we need
componenttext: Yes, I think, certainly, you don't. And with the supplies that we have, with committed deals didn't close and that assume they're all going to come back that simply, I think, clearly, we need to derate some of the feedback that we get and I think we need to invest some caution into this. And likewise, frankly, I think we need to see what other companies are reporting that as January closed to see if this is common or not. So I think that there's just a natural sense of conservatism, both in terms of the forecast we received and likewise, our own judging of those forecast as a result of this. I mean, simply put, we came out last quarter relatively bullish. I mean, when a lay out the valance, we were pushing the cloud story came out of insight, we have a lot of momentum, the feedback on the cloud and the hybrid cloud from the customers and partners has been tremendous. We did a dramatic expansion of the portfolio with refreshers of E-Series, introduction of the StorageGRID Webscale, we acquired the SteelStore product, the release of 8.3. So very strong about the portfolio, felt very strong about the forecast and I think, we came out of this last call, actually, relative excited where we're heading. So that's why we're really doubly disappointed about all of this. I don't in the end if suddenly there was a competitive disjunk, competitive disjoint or some type of quality issue or some type of product issue, but there's really none of that. So things were pretty much normal curve as far as we look at the quarter as it played out until we get to the end.

componenttextpreview: I guess, I wanted to circle back around this January commentary and see if you guys could -- those 40 deals, I guess, Tom, that you're talking about, is there any regional pattern that you spotted? I mean, did you see particular regions worsening in Janua
componenttext: I guess, I wanted to circle back around this January commentary and see if you guys could -- those 40 deals, I guess, Tom, that you're talking about, is there any regional pattern that you spotted? I mean, did you see particular regions worsening in January and others not? Do you see just sort of across the board in January things are not coming through as you would expect it? And then I'll also just as a follow-up to that, why you've given the comment, do you think that can you have direct impact from people suggesting that maybe budgets got reset? And kind of in January they can't do the deal because there some sort of a trend in terms of enterprise budget?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, the budget reset is exactly what I'm saying. So I think exciting that, that's clearly the case. But I think in terms of markets in general, certainly, energy was 1 that kind of jumped out of people being very, very cautious, obviously, with t
componenttext: Yes, I mean, the budget reset is exactly what I'm saying. So I think exciting that, that's clearly the case. But I think in terms of markets in general, certainly, energy was 1 that kind of jumped out of people being very, very cautious, obviously, with the movement of the price of oil. And I think certainly on the oil and gas, it has a negative impact, presumably it will help the rest of the industry, but I think that's a lot more diffused now taking the time to flow through. So I'd say probably the only segment that I'd say that we could clearly identify with relatively urgent caution would be oil and gas. But I'd say, most of the business is spread around. I mean, other sectors were very robust. One of the things that we talked about in prior calls was I believe that we're going to see solid growth on the federal side in the second half of the year easier compared to last year. That entirely came through. So if I think about the roadmap we've had here, we communicated at Analyst Day, we talked about of a rebound in federal in terms of growth in the second half of the year, we certainly saw that. We talked about focus on the enterprise and certainly saw record $1 million[ph] deals with certainly saw that, we certainly saw[ph] the $1 million[ph] deals. And I think overall, became a number of those things were on tract and that's what kind of left last quarter with, in terms of how we felt about the second half of the year. So I think some of the things came together and but other ones didn't. I think we sense that FX was clearly an issue, that will certainly comment that we have last quarter. And I think that's proven to be a bigger issue that we originally thought and Nick quantified that. And likewise, it's not just an issue for us or their competitors, is also an issue for our customers, because impact on their buying.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Steven Milunovich of UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Steven Milunovich of UBS.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Tom, did you say that there's a change in sales management? Could you talk a bit more about that if that's true. Who's in place now? And you also talked about investments in go-to-market. Could you talk a bit about what those investments are? And Nick, ou
componenttext: Tom, did you say that there's a change in sales management? Could you talk a bit more about that if that's true. Who's in place now? And you also talked about investments in go-to-market. Could you talk a bit about what those investments are? And Nick, our work going to see kind of a pick up in the SG&A to revenue ratio in the fourth quarter?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't think that it's any secret that certainly with hard new head of global sales, and we also have new leadership in the Americas Commercial business. I should point out that those -- that the leader of that business is the person who led our fed
componenttext: Yes, I don't think that it's any secret that certainly with hard new head of global sales, and we also have new leadership in the Americas Commercial business. I should point out that those -- that the leader of that business is the person who led our federal business to #1 market share in the federal space. So it's the person that has a very strong track record, somebody we have a lot of confidence in. So could it be some measure of them not being with their guys and judging the forecast, I think, certainly, that's a factor. But I think, general, these are people that we're pleased with the work that Randy's doing, certainly Mark's had the great history. And so we're confident in the team. So I wouldn't want to signal any message that there's a change in the team, change is in process, perhaps that impacted the forecasting, I'm guessing that, that's a factor. But we're talking about 2 people who practice really deep inspection. And like I said on the Monday of the quarter was over, I had very, very detailed report of what happened in the quarter before. So deals that happened, deals that didn't happen, why didn't happen and what we should expect going forward.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve, this is Nick, let me just add to that comment and answer your question on SG&A revenue. On the operating expenses, what Tom mentioned in his comments, this is also going to be an environment where we're going to position our investments for highest
componenttext: Steve, this is Nick, let me just add to that comment and answer your question on SG&A revenue. On the operating expenses, what Tom mentioned in his comments, this is also going to be an environment where we're going to position our investments for highest return activities. So to the degree, we're investing in certain areas and pushing investments in some was going to hold the investment in others. I think that's really important from the perspective of the business model and running the business going forward. So I don't see a material change in Q4 as an example of this SG&A to revenue. Certainly, and we'll give guidance in May for next year and we'll talk about in Q1, we'll go a question at a time and give you our perspective a quarter at a time. You always, a lot of times, Q1 was a little disjointed. Why? Because top line is the sequential decline in top line from Q4 to Q1. Some will go through all of that math. But to your specific point of Q4, I don't see a substantial or a material change in the SG&A or the operating expense to revenue ratios here.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Kathryn Huberty of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Kathryn Huberty of Morgan Stanley.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: How do we reconcile the comments on the weak January and delayed deals with DSOs that were up 6 days at the end of the quarter? And then also does the limited recovery and branded growth after refreshing the product portfolio, change your thinking on acqu
componenttext: How do we reconcile the comments on the weak January and delayed deals with DSOs that were up 6 days at the end of the quarter? And then also does the limited recovery and branded growth after refreshing the product portfolio, change your thinking on acquisitions as it relates to just broadening out the product portfolio?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. I think the DSO is a function of timing of shipments and invoicing more than anything else. So with the elongated sales cycles, we're still back-end loaded although we didn't take all those business in the end. But that said, I don't think there's rea
componenttext: No. I think the DSO is a function of timing of shipments and invoicing more than anything else. So with the elongated sales cycles, we're still back-end loaded although we didn't take all those business in the end. But that said, I don't think there's really anything more the DSO story. The other question about that, acquisitions? I think, acquisitions, I don't think this changes our opinions in acquisitions. I think we will continue to move ahead with tuck-in acquisitions that expand our portfolio, we did 2 this past quarter. Still the one that got through the headlines and I think we will continue to do that, that should be a normal course of business. I wouldn't expect that to neither accelerate nor decline. I think on the question of larger deals, those tend to be very, very, asynchronous and hard to predict. So I think from our point of view, if I look at transactions that we've done, E-Series branded had a very, very strong quarter up 100% again. If I look at on-demand insight, which is also an acquired technology, that was also -- had a very, very good quarter. So I think the success of our acquired businesses has been very good. So from my point of view, I think we'll continue to do tuck-in acquisitions. In terms of larger deals, we get don't get to predict when they are going to be available or when they are going to come about. But certainly, our recent record has been pretty good. And for the right transaction at the right price, when that's executable, we'll certainly move ahead with that. But I wouldn't want to predict any rate or any increased desire or decreased desire to pursue those.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: And maybe just a comment to where we take that DSO comment, Katy, and take it with the overall cash, I mean, I think that cash and cash conversion as a percent of revenue in Q3 was just a little bit later than we typically do. However, we do have a strong
componenttext: And maybe just a comment to where we take that DSO comment, Katy, and take it with the overall cash, I mean, I think that cash and cash conversion as a percent of revenue in Q3 was just a little bit later than we typically do. However, we do have a strong quarter in front of us here. So when I look at the overall statistics and the overall expectations in terms of cash generation this year, I don't see any change there at all. And I see us landing right inside the types of metrics we've talked about and modeled for the 3-year period time, certainly we talked in the last interim update.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of James Kisner with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of James Kisner with Jefferies.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, just wanted to verify something, was there any particular product lines at all that sort of some more deal? Just regionally and look at year-over-year rates, but Europe and Asia, they're both down a lot sequentially here on a year-over-year basis, b
componenttext: Okay, just wanted to verify something, was there any particular product lines at all that sort of some more deal? Just regionally and look at year-over-year rates, but Europe and Asia, they're both down a lot sequentially here on a year-over-year basis, but Asia had a tough compare. Were there any kind of regional differences in terms of the activity you're seeing?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would say one thing to bear in mind with the year-over-year comparison of Asia and especially in  [indiscernible] you've got the currency component of that. There is a currency component because in Canada, South America and the U.S. as well, or the Amer
componenttext: I would say one thing to bear in mind with the year-over-year comparison of Asia and especially in  [indiscernible] you've got the currency component of that. There is a currency component because in Canada, South America and the U.S. as well, or the Americas number but not that big. So I'd say, certainly, the FX one, there's really 2 question in play, one of them is the relative performance and the other one is deals that we actually had in the pipeline that we were expecting to close. So I think we're looking at both of those differently. Overall, in terms of our international business, the immediacy in dealing with FX, obviously, the Russia situation, even the French situation late in the quarter were all factors. And I think overall, from a booking perspective, they did quite well. So actually, the numbers don't show it, I'm actually quite pleased with the EMEA team. Asia-Pac is not a unified region, all the different geographies perform differently. But I think overall, they did well. We saw growth in China again, certainly, the China haven't been great, but I think the team continues to make progress. And so I think the biggest surprise relative to what we thought was going to be is in the Americas and particularly, in the Americas not federal.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: The product lines to follow-up on [indiscernible] or had much more efficiency?
componenttext: The product lines to follow-up on [indiscernible] or had much more efficiency?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Not in terms of split deals. I think that the category on split deals is really a function of size rather than product.
componenttext: Not in terms of split deals. I think that the category on split deals is really a function of size rather than product.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Amit Daryanani of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Amit Daryanani of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Tom, I guess, a question for you, you talked there's about adding more boots to the ground, adding more product specialist. How much of headcount increase do you anticipate doing? What's timeline to doing that? Is it 1 quarter or 2 or 3 quarters? And what
componenttext: Tom, I guess, a question for you, you talked there's about adding more boots to the ground, adding more product specialist. How much of headcount increase do you anticipate doing? What's timeline to doing that? Is it 1 quarter or 2 or 3 quarters? And what sort of payback to you expect in terms of branded growth escalating? What kind of headcount additions you wanted to do? And how do you see in the other side in terms of branded growth?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think at this point, we're not ready to quantify that. I think, that's a model we're working through on our own. But obviously, it is we something that we think is going to move the needle and something that we want to move the needle this coming
componenttext: Well, I think at this point, we're not ready to quantify that. I think, that's a model we're working through on our own. But obviously, it is we something that we think is going to move the needle and something that we want to move the needle this coming fiscal year. So it's not something that's going to move the needle in the immediate term, I don't think that we're going our people in the full quarter in a very, very short period of time. There'll be a sliding scale in terms of how they ultimately ramp up. So the real impact to that will probably towards the middle -- the end of next year. But the investment will be front ended. And as Nick indicated, in terms of as we think about our full year business model, as our full attention operate within the bounds of the business model we have previously communicated. But if I look at it, it's independent of the individual issues at the end of last quarter. If I look at our ratios and I look at our investments, we've done a substantial expansion of the portfolio. Within that portfolio has been carved out for specialists to drive things like E-Series and on command. I think that's paid off quite nicely for us. As we think about adding new products for the portfolio, whether it be storage or SteelStore, we're going to do some of that. So I expect all of those investments to come in. While in the meantime, we still need to be cultivating new accounts and new opportunities for Clustered ONTAP. The other one is, I think, that our partners are a key part of this. I think, investment in the partners so they come to speed on the new products since they're pitching in success and successfully be self-sufficient and pursuing these opportunities. And likewise, helping customers with immigration of Clustered ONTAP as the go-to-market activities that, I think, have immediate impact or relatively near-term impact on the business. But the simple fact of the matter is, if sales force productivity was the issue and they were not anywhere near quota and they were suboptimal because we don't have the products and we didn't have competitive technology, then I think we're making an entirely different investment choice. But the feeling is that the portfolio was strong and we just don't have enough people out there promoting it, selling it, serving customers. That's the investment that we want to make within the confines of the business model that we talked about.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ken Suva with Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ken Suva with Citi.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's Jim Suva here from Citi. [indiscernible] going through a little bit of shifting of the sales people over the past 12 or 24 months out of certain areas and the focus of other areas. And then today on the conference call, you mentioned any to really ge
componenttext: It's Jim Suva here from Citi. [indiscernible] going through a little bit of shifting of the sales people over the past 12 or 24 months out of certain areas and the focus of other areas. And then today on the conference call, you mentioned any to really get the kind of feet going in the right people, the right place but yet expense areas to be in a relatively normal, would expect. So can you help explain what's different? Meaning, you've kind of been shifting a little bit in the past 12 to 24 months and you're saying it isn't around. So what's different? Or how should we think about what you're truly doing different to address these, especially if the expenses are not going higher?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that there's really 2 questions here, one of them is the shifting of the resources within an envelope and the other one is the total envelope. So I think, clearly, we've been doing shifting of resources within the envelope. I think across th
componenttext: Well, I think that there's really 2 questions here, one of them is the shifting of the resources within an envelope and the other one is the total envelope. So I think, clearly, we've been doing shifting of resources within the envelope. I think across the entire company, we've worked very hard at that. And I think that manifest itself in terms of the engineering choice that we made and the price that we're bringing to market and we were able to do that by deemphasizing other products of moving out of certain spaces. We've certainly seen it in terms of carving out part of the sales resource to focus on some of these newer products, I talked about E-Series and on command and that has worked out well for us. And I also thought that we spoke at Analyst Day around the enterprise strategy and getting our partners more self-sufficient in the mid-sized business so we can migrate some of our resources against the bigger opportunities in the enterprise. So we've seen that $1 million deals. And so if we look at that data and that is more specialist around the new products generate sales, if we look at moving more resource to the enterprise, we'll generate more $1 million deals. If we can continue to make our partner self-sufficient and continue that and widen the total umbrella, the total number of people engaged in that, I think, it's hard to conclude that there's an opportunity for growth in that and that's the knob that we want to turn. Certainly, Clustered ONTAP has been a big investment, 8.3 is a culminating release for that. We needed to get that done, we need to get customers migrate to it. We certainly have to finish investments so we're making the other key technologies around all-flash FAS and flash in general. But I think we're ready to ship that transition towards field going activities now that the product arsenal is ready.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Jim, I might just add, in the context of operating expense envelope of just under $3 billion on an annual basis, we believe we have the opportunity to shift investment for highest return activities.
componenttext: And Jim, I might just add, in the context of operating expense envelope of just under $3 billion on an annual basis, we believe we have the opportunity to shift investment for highest return activities.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Shrini of Summit Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Shrini of Summit Research.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: The question I have is that regarding your flash. Flash, I don't know whether you commented on flash, I missed earlier part of the call. The question is that, you have a single controller device and its limiting your option to market. As we look at the fl
componenttext: The question I have is that regarding your flash. Flash, I don't know whether you commented on flash, I missed earlier part of the call. The question is that, you have a single controller device and its limiting your option to market. As we look at the flash opportunity out there, what [indiscernible] dominant flash, perhaps second in the market, at 25%?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, you're just talking about 1 product in the portfolio. We actually have the EF product, which is doing quite well. We've got the flash product and we also have the all-flash FAS. So -- and then we've got the hybrid arrays that also have flash. We cer
componenttext: Well, you're just talking about 1 product in the portfolio. We actually have the EF product, which is doing quite well. We've got the flash product and we also have the all-flash FAS. So -- and then we've got the hybrid arrays that also have flash. We certainly talked at Analyst Day and our view of this is that flash is a compelling technology, it's got a compelling set of deployments and they're all different factors, there's flash in the hose, there's all-flash arrays, there's hybrid arrays and all of those are going to be important. And a key component for us, ultimately, is not any of the individual products or any of the individual categories it's about total flash under management which is huge year-over-year. So from our perspective, I think, we're absolutely in the flash game. I think FlashRay array has been a key driver of innovation for us. We've seen not only FlashRay in its own incarnation, but FlashRay technology integrated and introduced in the form of all-flash FAS and EF as well. But all-flash FAS, clearly, as a product that a team who's familiar with, it had a very, very big growth quarter. And overall, I think that the idea of an all-flash FAS, instead of a stand-alone point product, it's actually be a node of a cluster that's compatible with all of our data movers in all of our storage efficiency and all of our scale out capability, it's a compelling value proposition. So I think FlashRay is going to serve a segment of the market, we continue to invest in it. It's in customers hands and we're getting a feedback around the key efficiency and performance and ease-of-use component. But that's not the totality of the flash portfolio. In fact, the overall majority of our flash is in the other products. And in fact, the all-flash FAS, which is only introduced quite 1.5 quarters ago, is actually the one that's ramping the hardest of all of those, and we're pretty pleased with the use cases. And what you'll see from that is, in fact, from a number of our products, compelling performance benchmarks that we're going to publish in the very, very near future. I think, from a performance perspective, certainly all-flash FAS has a feature set far beyond any other flash and compelling performance and compelling efficiency. I think you'll see a lot of more of that product in the new future as well, while we continue to evolve and develop FlashRay to serve the segments that it's targeted at.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Joe Wittine with Longbow Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Joe Wittine with Longbow Research.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the headcount you're adding, I think you're saying anymore product specialists. So what exactly are you're referring to? Is it more resources for the ramping flash business? Or maybe the service provider business? Or certain market verticals? I think j
componenttext: On the headcount you're adding, I think you're saying anymore product specialists. So what exactly are you're referring to? Is it more resources for the ramping flash business? Or maybe the service provider business? Or certain market verticals? I think just a little bit more clarity would be helpful.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would have -- yes, I don't want to leave a misperception there. I think, first and foremost, what any people are carrying numbers whose job it is to close business and bring business in. So product specialists, I talked about them in the category o
componenttext: Yes, I would have -- yes, I don't want to leave a misperception there. I think, first and foremost, what any people are carrying numbers whose job it is to close business and bring business in. So product specialists, I talked about them in the category of the product specialist have been successful, but within the fix-sized envelope, they come at eh expense of the generalists that are selling more -- the standard product and pursuing new accounts and those type of things. I think we want to be able to both of these are the same time. So I think we have invested in those overlay. I'd say, the increment from here will be not merely a significant percentage wise. What we're really looking to do is getting more people out there, getting in front of new customers, new customer acquisitions and deeper into our largest, biggest customers. So I'd say that the reason why I brought the product specialist is within the fixed envelope, the more product specialist you have, the less generalists you have. And our view is that we need more generalists out there, pushing the ONTAP-base products. Pursuant to our enterprise strategy, we've proven that we can get big deals if we move in that direction and now we want to get more people out there cultivating new accounts, deeper and existing accounts and bringing more big deals.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Nehal Chokshi with the Maxim Group.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Nehal Chokshi with the Maxim Group.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: The large deals have been pushed out in favor of service agreements. Is there any correlation to Cloud ONTAP having come generally global? Is this potentially creating any further evaluation? Do you expect this to become a material part of these large dea
componenttext: The large deals have been pushed out in favor of service agreements. Is there any correlation to Cloud ONTAP having come generally global? Is this potentially creating any further evaluation? Do you expect this to become a material part of these large deals? And can you give metrics around Cloud ONTAP at this point as well?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't think that Cloud ONTAP is changing that. I think -- I don't think Cloud ONTAP is a substitute necessarily for the type of system that we're selling on Cloud ONTAP on-premise. I think Cloud ONTAP is a completion of a story, it's an option for
componenttext: Well, I don't think that Cloud ONTAP is changing that. I think -- I don't think Cloud ONTAP is a substitute necessarily for the type of system that we're selling on Cloud ONTAP on-premise. I think Cloud ONTAP is a completion of a story, it's an option for test, development and back up and flexibility in DR. But I don't think it's changing the dynamic as to why buy on on-premise system or do I buy that? Now, there's actually a fair amount of activity around Cloud ONTAP. The numbers of hours is in the 40,000 range. So those are people kicking the tires, playing with it, some people are actually using it in production. But really what I see Cloud ONTAP is the completion of our end-to-end, seamless data management storage with the cloud. So I can run in Cloud ONTAP on 1 extreme, I could run on-premise, yet our private search, which I've seen a lot of acceleration, that's actually 1 of my favorite use cases. But overall, I don't think that, that's really disrupting it. I think the Cloud ONTAP is basically, at this point, is symbolic and emblematic of end-to-end seamless cloud strategy and proving that it's real. But I don't think it's in the near-term business, that's actually not a concern of mine.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Benjamin Reitzes of Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Benjamin Reitzes of Barclays.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: My questions around gross margin. What is the implied FX hit sequentially to the gross margin versus the pricing hit and mix? And to that end, you seem to get more price aggressive is sort of the premise as well versus some of the upstart competition.
componenttext: My questions around gross margin. What is the implied FX hit sequentially to the gross margin versus the pricing hit and mix? And to that end, you seem to get more price aggressive is sort of the premise as well versus some of the upstart competition.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ben, if you're talking about Q4 gross margins, there's a point of FX in there. So I think you need to consider that. I wouldn't suggest that in there is any additional price aggressiveness. I think the pricing has been -- has really been at this rate for
componenttext: Ben, if you're talking about Q4 gross margins, there's a point of FX in there. So I think you need to consider that. I wouldn't suggest that in there is any additional price aggressiveness. I think the pricing has been -- has really been at this rate for some time, right? So those dynamics in pricing. And from time to time, we did deeply discount. There are -- all of those type of things that we manage as part of managing the business. So there is not an incremental built in to our gross margin guidance. We also inside our structure, inside our COGS structure, drive a set of efficiencies. And frankly, over the last several years, have been driving an increasing set of efficiencies. So I think all of that levels out in the end. And I think the thing to remember is there's a point of FX in that -- year-over-year impact of FX in that Q4 guidance.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: What's the sequential impact to the FX?
componenttext: What's the sequential impact to the FX?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think -- I don't have that off the top of my head here, Ben.
componenttext: Well, I think -- I don't have that off the top of my head here, Ben.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our final question comes from the line of Mark Kelleher with D. A. Davidson.
componenttext: And our final question comes from the line of Mark Kelleher with D. A. Davidson.

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right, most of my questions have been asked by now, but let me just ask about SteelStore. Where does that fit in to your expectations going forward, particularly on the cost side, but also on the top line for the next few quarters?
componenttext: All right, most of my questions have been asked by now, but let me just ask about SteelStore. Where does that fit in to your expectations going forward, particularly on the cost side, but also on the top line for the next few quarters?

headline: NetApp, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, what skills are effectively is, is a backup of clients that integrated with the cloud. And clearly, from our point of view and those of you who inside at the Analyst Day, we talked about the economics of the cloud, cloud being a resting plac
componenttext:
Yes. I think, what skills are effectively is, is a backup of clients that integrated with the cloud. And clearly, from our point of view and those of you who inside at the Analyst Day, we talked about the economics of the cloud, cloud being a resting place for very low utilization data, like backup and archive. It's a way to seamlessly extend traditional backup all the way to the cloud is something at we felt very, very strongly about as an opportunity and that was really the motivation for pursuing SteelStore. So I say that post transaction, I think, a couple of things came out, one of which was this is a product with a fair amount visibility within Amazon. And the Amazon relationship is developing quite nicely around Cloud ONTAP, around NetApp Private Storage. And this 1 has become a third leg of the store in that relationship, in fact, they've actually referenced actually give us some reference accounts to pursue with this. So I think at this point, it's not material to the number that Nick just gave. it will be certainly not 0, in fact, it's already been non 0. I think, it's ahead of our initial forecast, but certainly, one of those very, very front end of that curve. So I think, so far so good, no regrets. But I think this is a bit too early to tell. But the real goal there is ultimately, is how do we enable the next-generation backup successfully integrates the cloud but is compatible with all the back up methodology that people currently deploy on-premise.
Okay, so first of all, thank you all for joining us today. As I think about the quarter that we just completed and I think about where we were last quarter, the evolution of the roadmap we introduced more new technology in the last 6 months whether it be a Clustered ONTAP 8.3, the acquisition of SteelStore, StorageGRID, on-command insight, E-Series, FlashRay, all-flash FAS and the momentum that we saw, both in terms of the last quarter, the forecast for this quarter, I think we felt very, very good about the business.
So as I talked in this prepared text, clearly, disappointed with the setback that we had, probably a little bit more disappointed, probably downright angry because I felt like we were in very, very good shape and we need to do better than that.
So as I think where we go forward, I think we are -- my belief and we're in as good as shape we are in the portfolio is unshaken. The execution issues, we will fix and we're going to make key investments within the bounds of our business model to fully exploit the full potential of this portfolio and drive growth to this company and that's our covenant.
So once again thank you for your time and I'll see you all next quarter.
